questions.text: Which of the following is an important epidemiological indicator for monitoring iodine deficiency in the Goiter Control program?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Urinary iodine excretion

Explanation:

Urinary iodine excretion is an important epidemiological indicator for monitoring iodine deficiency in the Goitre Control program.

Surveillance Indicators:

  • Urinary iodine excretion
  • Goiter prevalence (Option A)
  • Prevalence of cretinism
  • Measurement of serum T4 and TSH levels
  • prevalence of neonatal hypothyroidism.

Goitre Control Programme:

  • The aim is to increase iodine intake.
  • Neonatal hypothyroidism is a sensitive marker of environmental iodine deficiency. (Option D)
  • Serum T4 levels are more sensitive indicators of thyroid insufficiency than T3 levels. (Option C)

questions.text: A 30 year old woman has been complaining of patchy scalp hair loss for the past three weeks. Her past medical history is significant for vitiligo and thyroid disorders. On examination, she has a well-circumscribed area of hair loss over her occipital region, as shown below. Which among the following is not a feature of the disease described?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Trichoclasis

 

Explanation:

This patient with a history of autoimmune diseases and patchy hair loss as described in the question and image is suggestive of alopecia areata.

Trichoclasis is a feature of a feature of trichorrhexis nodosa, not alopecia areata.

Trichoclasis:

  • It is a transverse break in the hair shaft through a node seen in Trichorrhexis nodosa.
  • It is a hair shaft disorder where the hair shaft is excessively fragile due to the presence of nodes.
  • The end of the hair resembles a small paint brush with cortical fibers extruding through the fracture as shown in the image.
  • The proximal end of the hair shaft is normal, unlike in alopecia areata.

 

  • It is associated with rare genetic diseases like argininosuccinate lyase deficiency.
  • Clinical features: Sparse, brittle, and lustreless hair
  • Diagnosis is through physical examination and hair shaft microscopy
  • Treatment includes avoiding trauma to the hair and management of the medical cause.

 

The features of alopecia areata include

  • Ophiasis is scalp hair loss in the occipital region, whereas sisaipho is the opposite of this variant, with scalp hair loss sparing the temporal and occipital areas.
Ophiasis Sisaipho


 

  • Exclamation mark hair
  • Turning grey syndrome: It is a feature of alopecia areata where white hair are typically spared by immune cells, leading to loss of black hair with sparing of white hair
  • Nail pitting: Regular, geometric pitting of the nail bed as shown below.

Note: Psoriasis shows irregular pitting.

Treatment depends on the extent of the disease. Topical therapy for limited disease is done using intralesional steroids and contact immunotherapy whereas systemic therapy, Levamisole or Cyclosporine is used for extensive disease.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a history of IV drug use presents with fatigue, nausea, and mild jaundice. He reports a history of similar symptoms about 5 years ago, which resolved spontaneously. Laboratory testing shows elevated liver enzymes, and an ELISA test is positive for anti-HCV antibodies. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to confirm an active HCV infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) RT-PCR for HCV RNA
 

Explanation:

  • RT-PCR for HCV RNA is the gold standard for confirming active HCV infection.
  • While an ELISA test detects antibodies, it does not differentiate between past and active infections.
  • The presence of HCV RNA indicates ongoing viral replication and active infection.
  • The core antigen assay, though helpful for initial diagnosis and monitoring, is less sensitive than RT-PCR.

 

Hepatitis C Virus (HCV)

Classification

HCV belongs to the Flaviviridae family, genus Hepacivirus.
 

Structure and Genome
  • Spherical, 60 nm, enveloped virus with a positive-sense single-stranded RNA (ssRNA).
  • Structural proteins: Core protein (C), envelope glycoproteins (E1, E2).
  • Nonstructural proteins: NS2, NS3, NS4A, NS4B, NS5A, NS5B.
  • P7 membrane protein (NS1) functions as an ion channel.
 

Transmission
  • Primarily bloodborne: Transfusions, organ transplants, needle-sharing.
  • Vertical transmission (~6%) & rarely sexual transmission.
  • Not spread by breast milk, food, or casual contact.
 

Clinical Manifestation
  • Incubation: 15–160 days (average 50 days).
  • Asymptomatic in over 75% of cases.
  • Acute hepatitis in ~20%: usually mild or anicteric

Chronic Progression

  • Chronic Disease: 75–85% of cases progress to chronic disease.
  • Chronic Hepatitis: 60–70% of chronic cases.
  • Cirrhosis: 5–20% of cases with chronic infection.
  • Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC): 1–5% of cases; HCV accounts for ~25% of liver cancers.
 

Extrahepatic Manifestations

Immune complex deposition can cause:

  • Mixed cryoglobulinemia
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Arthritis and joint pain.

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • Antibody Detection Tests: ELISA is standard for initial screening with high sensitivity and specificity. Cannot differentiate active vs. past infections.
  • HCV Core Antigen Assay: Automated, cost-effective for active infection diagnosis and treatment monitoring. Less sensitive than RT-PCR. (Option A)
  • Molecular Methods (RT-PCR): Gold standard for confirming active infection; detects HCV RNA 2–3 weeks post-infection, used for viral load, treatment response, and genotype. (Option C)
  • Biopsy (Option B) is the gold standard for staging; Fibroscan (Option D) is a non-invasive alternative for assessing liver fibrosis.

Treatment
  • Goals: Prevent complications (e.g., cirrhosis, liver cancer) and achieve sustained viral response (SVR).
  • Sofosbuvir/velpatasvir is effective against all genotypes.
  • Duration: Typically 12–24 weeks, depending on genotype and liver status.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with recurrent infections and a history of autoimmune disease. Laboratory tests reveal a deficiency in complement component C3. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of this deficiency?

choices.text: Increased susceptibility to infections by Neisseria meningitidis
Impaired opsonization and phagocytosis, leading to severe bacterial infections
Enhanced immune complex clearance and reduced inflammation

questions.solution:
Impaired opsonization and phagocytosis due to C3 deficiency increases susceptibility to severe bacterial infections, particularly from pyogenic bacteria.

 

Complement Deficiency:

  • Definition: Complement deficiencies arise from genetic defects in complement components or regulatory proteins, compromising both innate and acquired immunity.
  • Clinical Manifestations: Vary from mild recurrent infections to severe life-threatening conditions.

Consequences of Complement Deficiency:

  • Impaired Immune Clearance: Reduced ability to clear microbial antigens and immune complexes leads to:
    • Recurrent Infections:
      • Increased susceptibility to bacterial and fungal infections, especially with C3 deficiencies.
      • Common infections include pneumonia, skin infections, and sepsis due to pyogenic bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae).
    • Neisserial Infections:
      • Terminal complement deficiencies (C5-C9) increase susceptibility to Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, leading to meningitis, septicaemia, and gonorrhoea. (Option A ruled out)
    • Autoimmune Diseases:
      • It is associated with conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) due to impaired clearance of immune complexes, resulting in tissue deposition, inflammation, and damage.

Specific Deficiencies and Associated Syndromes:

 

Deficiency

Condition/Clinical Manifestation

C1 Inhibitor Deficiency (Option C ruled out)

Hereditary angioneurotic oedema: Uncontrolled activation of classical pathway causes episodic swelling (can be life-threatening).

C3 Deficiency

Increased susceptibility to severe recurrent pyogenic infections; impaired opsonization, phagocytosis, and immune complex clearance.

C5-C9 Deficiencies

Increased susceptibility to bacteraemia, especially with Gram-negative diplococci; impaired formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC).

 

Enhanced immune complex clearance and reduced inflammation (option D) are incorrect, as C3 deficiency leads to impaired clearance and increased inflammation due to the accumulation of immune complexes.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases exclusively involves obligate hosts in its transmission cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Measles

Explanation:

  • Obligate hosts are the only hosts that are necessary for the completion of a pathogen's life cycle.
  • Person-to-person transmission is present.
  • E.g., Typhoid, Measles

Sleeping sickness (Option B): Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis) involves multiple hosts in its transmission cycle, not just obligate hosts. The cycle includes:

  • Tsetse flies (vector)
  • Humans (Main host for Trypanosoma brucei gambiense)
  • Wild and domestic animals (Reservoir hosts for Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense).
  • This complex cycle involves both obligate and non-obligate hosts.

 

Hydatid disease (Option C): Hydatid disease is caused by the tapeworm Echinococcus.

  • Definitive hosts: dogs and other canines
  • Intermediate hosts: sheep, cattle, humans This cycle doesn't rely solely on obligate hosts.

 

Filaria (Option D): Filariasis is caused by filarial worms (e.g., Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi). It involves multiple hosts in its transmission cycle: Mosquitoes (vector), Humans (main host)

questions.text: A 51-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and unintentional weight loss. A biopsy of the liver was done. Which of the following histopathological features is characteristic of the condition depicted in the biopsy image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mallory-Denk bodies

Explanation: The histopathological feature characteristic of the condition depicted in the biopsy image is Mallory-Denk bodies, a hallmark of both alcohol-induced and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis.

  • These are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions seen in hepatocytes.
  • They comprise intermediate filaments, primarily cytokeratin 8 and 18, and other proteins like ubiquitin.
  • They indicate cellular injury and are often associated with hepatocyte ballooning and inflammation.

 

Mallory - Denk bodies are also seen in (New Indian WATCH)

  • Non alcoholic fatty liver disease
  • Indian childhood cirrhosis
  • Wilson’s disease
  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Tumors like hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Chronic cholestasis
  • Focal nodular Hyperplasia


 

Ground-glass hepatocytes (Option B):

This morphological change is seen in chronic hepatitis B infection, where hepatocytes display a granular, homogenous eosinophilic cytoplasm due to the accumulation of HBsAg in the swollen smooth endoplasmic reticulum.

 

 

Councilman bodies (Option C):

Councilman bodies (or acidophilic bodies) are eosinophilic, round structures representing hepatocyte apoptosis. They are typically seen in acute viral hepatitis and indicate severe hepatocellular injury.

 

 

Glycogenated hepatocytes (Option D):

  • Glycogenated hepatocytes are hepatocytes with increased intracytoplasmic glycogen content.
  • This finding is often seen in conditions associated with metabolic disturbances, such as glycogen storage diseases or acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 3-month-old female infant presents with feeding difficulties and a noticeable facial deformity. On examination, the infant has a unilateral complete cleft involving the left lip, extending through the alveolus and hard palate, with an intact soft palate on the left side. The right side of the lip and palate are completely intact. What is the LAHSAL classification for this patient's cleft abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 00HSAL

 

Explanation:

Understanding LAHSAL Classification:

LAHSAL is a system used to describe cleft lip and palate in a topographic and symmetrical manner, from the patient's right to left:

Letter Meaning
L Lip
A Alveolus
H Hard palate
S Soft palate
Capital letter Complete cleft
Lowercase letter Incomplete cleft
"0" Normal segment

 

So:

  • The first 3 letters (L-A-H) refer to the right side

  • The last 3 letters (S-A-L) refer to the left side

Breakdown of the Case:

  • Left side:

    • Lip cleft → L (complete, hence capital)

    • Alveolus cleft → A

    • Hard palate cleft → H

    • Soft palate is intact → S = 0

  • Right side: Everything intact → L-A-H = 0-0-0

Putting this into LAHSAL:

  • Right side (L-A-H) = 0-0-0

  • Left side (S-A-L) = H-A-L (from back to front)

Final Code (Right to Left) = 00HSAL

 

LAH000 (Option B): Incorrect, implies cleft on right side.

LAHS00 (Option C): Incorrect, implies soft palate cleft on right and lip/alveolus normal.

LAHSAL (Option D): Implies bilateral complete cleft (both sides involved).

questions.text:
Match the following Delancey level of support of the uterus and the ligaments involved, and what condition it causes:


	
		
			
			Delancey Level of Support
			
			
			Ligaments Involved
			
			
			Conditions
			
		
		
			
			1. Level 1
			
			
			A. Pubocervical fascia and rectovaginal fascia
			
			
			I. Cystocele
			
		
		
			
			2. Level 2
			
			
			B. Levator ani muscle
			
			
			II. Enterocele
			
		
		
			
			3. Level 3
			
			
			C. Uterosacral and cardinal ligaments
			
			
			III. Urethrocele
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-C-II, 2-A-I, 3-B-III

Explanation:

DeLancey Identified Three Levels of Pelvic Organ Support:

DeLancey Level of Support

Ligaments Involved

Conditions

Level 1
  • Supported by uterosacral and cardinal ligaments
  • Supports the uterus and vaginal vault.
  • The cervix remains at or just above the ischial spines.

Damage can lead to:

  • Uterine descent
  • Enterocele
  • Vault descent

Level 2
  • Supported by pelvic fascia and paracolpos, the vagina connects to the lateral pelvic wall via the arcus tendinous fascia pelvis.
  • Includes pubocervical fascia (anteriorly), rectovaginal fascia, and septum (posteriorly).

Damage can lead to:

  • Cystocele
  • Rectocele

Level 3
  • Supported by the levator ani muscle.
  • Supports the lower one-third of the vagina.
  • Forms a platform that compresses pelvic organs (uterus and upper vagina) during straining.

Damage can lead to:

  • Urethrocele
  • Gaping introitus 
  • Deficient perineum

questions.text: A 42-year-old African American woman presents with visual disturbances. Eye examination reveals vitreous cells, snowball opacities, and candle wax drippings. Which type of uveitis is seen in the underlying disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Panuveitis

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario suggests ocular sarcoidosis (granulomatous panuveitis).

 

Ocular Sarcoidosis Overview:
 

  • Disease Characteristics:
    • Granulomatous, multi-system disease with unknown cause
    • Non-caseating epithelioid cell granulomas
    • Common in young adults (20-50 years), more frequent in women and individuals of African descent

 

  • Common Presentations:
    • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
    • Pulmonary infiltration
    • Skin and eye lesions

 

  • Ocular Lesions:
    • Occur in 20-50% of cases
    • Types: Sarcoid uveitis, conjunctival lesions, lacrimal gland involvement

 

Sarcoid Uveitis

  • Prevalence: Accounts for 2% of uveitis cases
  • Types and Signs: Sarcoidosis is associated with Panuveitis

Type of Uveitis

Signs

Anterior (Option A)

Granulomatous iridocyclitis, iris nodules, large mutton fat KPs, anterior chamber cells and flare, posterior synechiae

Intermediate

Vitreous cells, snowball opacities, snowbanking

Posterior (Option C)

Choroidal and retinal granulomas, cystoid macular edema, periphlebitis retinae with candle wax droppings appearance

Peripheral Multifocal Chorioretinitis (Option D)

Small, punched-out atrophic spots, highly suggestive of sarcoidosis

Uveoparotid Fever (Heerfordt’s Syndrome)

Bilateral granulomatous panuveitis, painful parotid gland enlargement, cranial nerve palsies, skin rashes, fever, malaise

 

  • Complications:
    • Complicated cataract
    • Inflammatory glaucoma
    • Cystoid macular edema

 

Other Ocular Lesions

  • Conjunctival Lesions:
    • Sarcoid nodules
    • Keratoconjunctivitis sicca

 

  • Lacrimal Glands:
    • Enlargement can lead to Mickulicz’s syndrome (with diffuse salivary gland swelling)

questions.text: Interpret the following ECG
questions.solution: Notice the non-conducted P waves buried at the end of T waves that are marked in red. There is alternate conducted P wave followed by qRS and non-conducted waves buried at end of T wave. This is 2:1 block. Option A has serial prolongation of PR interval. Option B has normal PR interval with sudden dropped beat. Option C will have all non-conducted P waves. Think of third degree heart block as divorce between Atria and ventricles.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD for regular Pap smear screening. The smear suggests a low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Which of the following abnormal cell types was most likely seen on the smear?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Koilocytes

 

Explanation:

Koilocytes are abnormal cervical cells seen on pap smears, indicative of HPV infections of the cervix.

  • They are squamous epithelial cells with nuclear enlargement, coarse chromatin, perinuclear cavitation, and irregular nuclear membranes.
  • A rim of condensed cytoplasm often surrounds the perinuclear cavitation, giving the cell a "halo" appearance.

Doderlein cells (Option A):

  • Doderlein cells are large, glycogen-rich squamous epithelial cells in the vaginal epithelium, associated with Lactobacillus species.
  • A reduction or absence of Doderlein cells can indicate pathological conditions such as bacterial vaginosis.

 

Hobnail cells (Option B):

  • Hobnail cells are found in clear cell carcinoma of the ovary.

 

Arias-Stella reaction cells (Option C):

  • Arias-Stella reaction cells are a type of glandular epithelial cell found in the endometrium during pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy, or pathological conditions like gestational trophoblastic disease.

questions.text: 50-year-old hypertension patient presents with heaviness in chest with shortness of breath on climbing stairs. ECG done in ER is normal. He was admitted in your hospital last year with diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome and was discharged on oral medications with advice for monthly follow up which he did not follow. Which of the following investigations is best for diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution: The current case presentation is of chronic stable angina. ECG will be normal at rest. The best non invasive test to diagnose CSA is Coronary CT angiography.

questions.text: The following sign in breast MRI is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The "Linguine Sign" is a characteristic MRI finding of an intracapsular breast implant rupture.

  • Intracapsular Rupture: The implant shell breaks, but the fibrous capsule remains intact, preventing silicone from leaking out.
    • On MRI, the collapsed shell appears as multiple wavy lines, resembling linguine.
    • On USG, it appears a stepladder appearance.
  • Extracapsular Rupture: Silicone escapes beyond the fibrous capsule, often seen as the "Snowstorm Sign" on ultrasound. (Option C)

Other MRI Signs:

  • "Keyhole Sign" / "Teardrop Sign": Silicone on both sides of a radial fold suggests rupture.
  • "Salad Oil Sign": Seen in double-lumen implant rupture with mixing of saline and silicone.

Management: Surgical removal is recommended to prevent silicone migration and complications.

 

Fibrocystic breast disease (Option A):

  • Benign condition with lumpy, painful breasts. Common imaging findings include cystic changes, fibrosis, and adenosis.

 

Fat necrosis of the breast (Option D):

  • Occurs due to trauma or surgery, presenting as oil cysts, calcifications, or irregular masses on mammography or ultrasound.

questions.text:
Match the following with their correct terms.


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			Exon
			
			
			i
			
			
			Non-coding region
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Intron
			
			
			ii
			
			
			One of the alternate forms of a single gene occupying a given position in a chromosome
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Locus
			
			
			iii
			
			
			Coding region
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			Allele
			
			
			iv
			
			
			Location of a gene on the chromosome
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1-iii, 2-i, 3-iv, 4-ii

 

Explanation:

 

Exon:

  • An exon is a coding region of a gene that contains the genetic information necessary for producing a functional protein.

 

Intron:

  • An intron is a non-coding region of a gene that intervenes between exons.
  • During gene expression, introns are removed from the pre-mRNA molecule through splicing, which allows exons to be joined together to form the final mRNA transcript before translation into a protein.

 

Locus:

  • A locus refers to the specific location of a gene or DNA sequence on a chromosome.

 

Allele:

  • An allele is one of the alternate forms of a single gene occupying a given position in a chromosome, which can lead to different traits or characteristics.
  • Alleles can be dominant or recessive.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with severe hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, irritability, and lethargy between feedings. Laboratory tests reveal elevated lactate, triglycerides, and uric acid. The child frequently feeds to manage hypoglycemia. Based on these findings, which condition is most likely responsible for the symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Von Gierke's Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I) is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, impairing glycogen breakdown and gluconeogenesis.
  • The key clinical features in this infant, such as severe hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, irritability, and lethargy between feedings, strongly suggest impaired glucose release from the liver.
  • Laboratory findings of elevated lactate, triglycerides, and uric acid further support Von Gierke’s disease due to defective glucose metabolism.
  • Frequent feedings are characteristic, as affected infants need continuous glucose intake to prevent hypoglycemia.

Von Gierke's Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I)

Cause

Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme

Pathophysiology

Inability to convert glucose-6-phosphate to glucose; leads to accumulation of glycogen, lactate, and triglycerides

Symptoms
  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Hepatomegaly and Renomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hyperuricemia and Hyperlipidemia

Diagnosis
  • Biochemical tests (hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia)
  • Genetic testing

Management
  • Frequent feedings with slow-release carbohydrates
  • Blood glucose monitoring
  • Medications for associated conditions
  • Liver transplantation (in severe cases)

Glycogen Storage Disorders (GSDs)

GSD Type Name Enzyme Deficiency Affected Organs Key Features
Type I Von Gierke's Disease Glucose-6-phosphatase Liver, Kidney Severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia
Type V McArdle's Disease (Option B ruled out) Muscle phosphorylase Skeletal Muscle Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria after exertion
Type VII Tarui's Disease (Option C ruled out) Muscle phosphofructokinase Muscle, RBCs Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, hemolytic anemia
Type VI Hers' Disease (Option D ruled out) Liver phosphorylase Liver Hepatomegaly, mild hypoglycemia, milder symptoms than Von Gierke's

 McArdle's Disease (Option B): Incorrect because it primarily affects muscle, leading to exercise intolerance and myoglobinuria rather than hypoglycemia.

Tarui's Disease (Option C): Incorrect because it affects muscle and red blood cells, leading to exercise intolerance and hemolytic anemia, not hypoglycemia.

Hers' Disease (Option D): Incorrect because it causes mild hypoglycemia without lactic acidosis, whereas this case presents with severe hypoglycemia and metabolic abnormalities.

questions.text: A couple seeks medical advice after their daughter presents with frequent nosebleeds and easy bruising. Lab investigations reveal prolonged bleeding time, prolonged aPTT, and a normal PT. A detailed history and a pedigree analysis were obtained, suspecting a genetic disorder. Based on the pedigree chart, what is this condition's most likely inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: B) Autosomal dominant


 

EXPLANATION:

 

The clinical presentation of a female with frequent nosebleeds, easy bruising, prolonged bleeding time & aPTT, and normal PT is suggestive of Von Willebrand disease.

 

Platelet Function & Factor VIII – 1-Molybdenum Deficiency

  • Platelet Adhesion:

    • Factor VIII is part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway

    • 1-Molybdenum deficiency → defective platelet adhesion → bleeding time ↑

  • Coagulation Defect:

    • Factor VIII cannot function normally → factor VIII activity ↓

    • Leads to prolonged APTT (activated partial thromboplastin time)

The pedigree chart shows a vertical transmission pattern with no skipping of generations and is suggestive of autosomal dominant inheritance.

Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern:

  • The mode of transmission is vertical. An affected person has an affected parent.
  • There is a 50% chance of the dominant trait being transmitted to offspring.
  • Both males and females are equally affected.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is examining the lungs of a newborn during an autopsy. The lungs appear mottled in color and occupy most of the thoracic cavity. However, when subjected to the hydrostatic test, portions of the lung tissue sink while others float. Microscopically, some areas show expanded alveoli lined with flat squamous cells, while other areas show closed alveoli lined with cuboidal cells. What is the most likely explanation for these conflicting findings?

choices.text: The infant was stillborn, and the floating lung portions are due to putrefaction
The infant was live-born but suffered from severe respiratory distress syndrome
The infant was live-born and partially breathed before death
The findings are inconclusive and could be due to artificial respiration attempts

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The infant was live-born and partially breathed before death

Explanation:

The findings support that the infant was live-born and partially respired before death, based on:

  • Mottled appearance of lungs and partial thoracic cavity expansion, indicating some aeration.
     
  • Mixed hydrostatic test results- some lung parts floated while others sank.
     
  • Microscopy showed:
     
    • Expanded alveoli lined with flat squamous cells (indicating respiration).
       
    • Closed alveoli lined with cuboidal/columnar cells (indicating unrespired areas).
       

Comparison: Respired vs. Unrespired Lung

Feature

Unrespired Lung (Stillborn)

Respired Lung (Live-born)

Color

Bluish red

Mottled

Volume

Small

Large, covers heart

Thoracic cavity

Not full

Fully occupied

Pleura

Loose, wrinkled

Taut, stretched

Margins

Sharp

Rounded

Surface

Smooth

Uneven

Consistency

Dense, firm, non-crepitant (liver-like)

Soft, spongy, elastic, crepitant

Ploucquet's test

1:70

1:35

Fodere's static test

30–40 g

60–70 g

Diaphragm level

4th–5th rib

6th–7th rib

Blood oozing

Little, frothless

Abundant, frothy

Hydrostatic test

Whole and parts sink in water

Floats in water

Alveoli

Not expanded

Expanded

Microscopy

Closed sacs with cuboidal/columnar lining

Dilated sacs with flat squamous lining and vascularity

 

The infant was stillborn, and the floating lung portions are due to putrefaction (Option A):
Incorrect because although putrefaction can produce gas leading to lung flotation, microscopy revealed expanded alveoli with flattened squamous cells, indicating actual respiration, not decomposition.

 

The infant was live-born but suffered from severe respiratory distress syndrome (Option B):
Incorrect because RDS usually leads to generalized alveolar collapse, not the mixed pattern of both inflated and collapsed alveoli observed here.

 

The findings are inconclusive and could be due to artificial respiration attempt (Option D):
Incorrect because artificial respiration typically causes more uniform aeration of the lungs. The patchy aeration pattern and histological evidence of both respired and unrespired areas support partial natural breathing, not artificial intervention alone.

questions.text: The microscopic examination of a wet mount preparation of stool from a patient with diarrhoea is shown below. Which organism is likely to exhibit this type of motility?
questions.solution:
The wet mount stool preparation displayed shows an organism exhibiting falling leaf-like motility, characteristic of Giardia lamblia (trophozoite is motile with a slow oscillation along its axis, resembling a falling leaf).

Types of motilities of microorganism:

Motility

Microorganism

Darting motility

Vibrio, Campylobacter

Swarming motility

Proteus

Tumbling motility

Listeria monocytogenes

Stately motility

Clostridia

Corkscrew motility

Treponema pallidum

Falling leaf motility

Giardia

Twitching motility

Eiknella corrodens

Jerky motility

Trichomonas vaginalis

Gliding motility

Mycoplasma

Lashing motility

Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman reports that for the past year, she has been experiencing severe anxiety whenever she leaves her home alone and while using public transport. She fears that if she experiences dizziness or shortness of breath, she will not be able to find help. Due to this fear, she has been unable to visit friends, shop, or attend social events without a companion. She has never had a panic attack. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Agoraphobia

Explanation:

This patient’s symptoms are classic for agoraphobia, a condition defined by marked fear or anxiety about being in situations where escape might be difficult or help might not be available in the event of developing panic-like or incapacitating symptoms (e.g., dizziness, shortness of breath).

Key features from the case:

  • Fear of leaving home alone
     
  • Avoidance of public settings (e.g., shopping, visiting friends, attending events)
     
  • Requires a companion to feel safe
     
  • No history of panic attacks (which rules out panic disorder)
     

Agoraphobia can occur with or without panic disorder. In this case, her fear is anticipatory (fear of what might happen), not a response to actual panic attacks.

Agoraphobia – Diagnostic Criteria Highlights (DSM-5):

 

Criterion

Description

Fear/anxiety about ≥2 situations

e.g., using public transport, open spaces, enclosed places, standing in line or being in a crowd, being outside the home alone

Thoughts

Escape might be difficult or help unavailable

Behavior

Actively avoided or endured with intense fear or only with a companion

Duration

Typically ≥6 months

Not better explained by another condition

e.g., social anxiety or specific phobia

Treatment:

Pharmacological, psychological, and combined treatments.

Psychological therapies:

  • Behavioral therapy: For rapid and complete reduction of agoraphobia, such as systematic desensitization, graded exposure.
  • Cognitive Behavioral therapy
  • Virtual therapy
  • Relaxation techniques

Pharmacotherapy:

  • Limited role.
  • Used to treat comorbid conditions like panic disorder.
  • SSRIs, along with Benzodiazepines (short-term).

 

Panic Disorder (Option A): Characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks and persistent concern about having future attacks lasting more than a month. Patients often develop anticipatory anxiety and behavioral changes, such as avoiding places where attacks have previously occurred. In this case, the primary concern is about avoiding situations due to fear of panic attacks, not recurrent panic attacks themselves. This option is incorrect.

 

Specific Phobia (Option B): Specific phobia refers to an intense fear of a particular object or situation (e.g., heights, animals, flying). The avoidance behavior in this case is not related to a specific object but to broader situations where escape might be difficult, which is more characteristic of agoraphobia. This option is incorrect.

 

Social anxiety disorder (Option C): It involves an intense fear of being judged or embarrassed in social or performance situations. The avoidance behavior in this case is not driven by fear of social scrutiny but by fear of being in places where escape might be difficult in case of a panic-like situation. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 3 year old child presents with a firm swelling on the bridge of the nose. Imaging reveals that the mass is encapsulated and has no connection to the brain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Glioma

Explanation:

Gliomas are independent masses that often present as firm, subcutaneous swellings on the bridge of the nose and are not connected to the brain.

Gliomas:

Definition: Congenital anomaly related to encephaloceles; "nipped-off" portions that become independent masses during embryonic development.

Characteristics:

 

Presentation Type

Description

Extranasal (60%)

Firm, subcutaneous swellings. Common locations: bridge of the nose, side of the nose, near the inner canthus (corner of the eye).

Intranasal (30%)

Located entirely within the nasal cavity.

Combined (10%)

Have both intranasal and extranasal components.

 

Treatment:

  • Extranasal gliomas: Encapsulated and easier to remove surgically via an external nasal approach.
  • Intranasal glioma: Minimally Invasive Endoscopic Surgery is essential for intranasal glioma to confirm diagnosis, prevent complications, and address cosmetic concerns.

Nasal polyps (Option A) typically arise from the nasal mucosa and are not encapsulated.

Encephaloceles (Option B) maintain a connection to the brain, unlike gliomas.

Dermoid cysts (Option D) are also firm but often contain skin elements like hair or sebaceous glands, and they are not encapsulated masses.

questions.text: Which of the following structures contributes to the formation of the marked part of the diaphragm (inferior view)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dorsal mesentery of esophagus

 

Explanation:

The marked part of the diaphragm corresponds to the crura of the diaphragm, which is primarily derived from the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus.

 

Part of Diaphragm

Source of Development

1. Central Tendon of Diaphragm

Septum transversum

2. Small Peripheral Part

Pleuroperitoneal Membrane

3. Crura of Diaphragm

Dorsal Mesentery of Esophagus

4. Large Peripheral Part

Mesoderm of Body Wall

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida gave birth to a healthy baby boy of 4 kg. She sustained an injury to the perineum involving internal and external anal sphincters. Which degree of perineal tear is this?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Third Degree

Explanation:

Degrees of perineal tear

Description

First Degree (Option A)

Injury to perineal skin only.

Second Degree (Option B)

Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter.

Third Degree (Option C)

Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both external and internal):

  • 3a: <50% of EAS thickness torn
  • 3b: >50% of EAS thickness torn
  • 3c: Both EAS and IAS torn

Fourth degree (Option D)

Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS) and anal epithelium.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with difficulty swallowing and changes in voice quality. Upon examination, the physician suspects a neurological issue affecting the muscles of the larynx and pharynx. Which nucleus is responsible for the motor innervation of these muscles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nucleus ambiguus

 

Explanation:

The nucleus ambiguus is the primary nucleus that provides motor innervation to the muscles of the larynx and pharynx via the vagus nerve.

 

Vagus Nerve (Cranial Nerve X)

  • This mixed nerve is primarily motor in function and the longest of the cranial nerves. 
  • Carry most of the parasympathetic output from the cranial region, including fibers from the cranial part of the accessory nerve.
  • Functional Components and Nuclei:

Functional Column

Function

Nucleus

Special Visceral Efferent

Supply muscles of the palate, pharynx, and larynx

Nucleus Ambiguus

General Visceral Efferent

Parasympathetic innervation to the heart, bronchial tree, and GIT

Dorsal Nucleus of the Vagus

(Option A)

Special Visceral Afferent

Taste sensations from the posterior part of the tongue and epiglottis

Nucleus Tractus Solitarius

(Option C)

General Visceral Afferent

Convey sensations from the mucous membranes of the pharynx, larynx, trachea, esophagus, and thoracic/abdominal viscera

Nucleus Tractus Solitarius & Dorsal Nucleus of Vagus

General Somatic Afferent

Carry sensations from the skin of the Auricle

Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of chronic constipation has been using over-the-counter laxatives for several months. During a routine colonoscopy, the gastroenterologist observes the following image. Which of the following is the implicated reason for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Senna

Explanation:

The Image shown is of Melanosis Coli, a benign condition where dark pigmentation of the colonic mucosa is seen on colonoscopy, often associated with the long-term use of anthraquinone-containing laxatives like Senna and Cascara.

 

Senna & Cascara:

  • Herbal Laxatives, which are a type of Stimulant laxatives.
  • It causes low-grade inflammation in the small and large bowel, stimulating intestinal motility and promoting the accumulation of water and electrolytes.
  • Other side effects of Senna/Cascara besides Melanosis Coli are nausea, vomiting and abdominal cramping.

 

Contraindications:

  • Pregnancy (Increased the risk of abortion due to contractions)
  • Intestinal Obstruction (can cause rupture of the intestine)
  • Before Colonoscopy (can interfere with colonoscopy findings)

questions.text:
To investigate the association between high cholesterol levels and the development of hypertension, researchers collected data from 100 patients with hypertension and 210 patients without disease. 60 patients had high cholesterol levels in the hypertensive group, while 30 patients had high cholesterol levels in the non-hypertensive group.

What are the odds of having high cholesterol levels in hypertensive patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 9.0

Explanation:

Calculation of Odds Ratio (OR):

  1. Identify the data:
    1. Cases with high cholesterol: 60
    2. Cases without high cholesterol: 40 (100 - 60)
    3. Controls with high cholesterol: 30
    4. Controls without high cholesterol: 180 (210 - 30)

Risk Factor/Exposure

High cholesterol

Low cholesterol

Hypertension

60 (a)

40 (b)

No hypertension

30 (c)

180 (d)
  1. Odds of exposure among cases: a/d = 60/40 = 1.5
  2. Odds of exposure among controls: = c/d = 30/180 = 0.1667
  3. Odds ratio (OR) = (odds of exposure among cases) / (odds of exposure among controls)

OR = ad/bc = 1.5 / 0.1667 = 9

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cardiac jelly is incorrect?

choices.text: Provide structural support during early heart development
Facilitates end-systolic occlusion, improving pumping efficiency
Store elastic energy during systole for the refilling phase of the heart.
Cellular matrix secreted by the endocardium in the developing heart.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cellular matrix secreted by the endocardium in the developing heart.

 

Explanation:

The cardiac jelly is an acellular matrix that is secreted by the myocardium in the developing heart.

Cardiac Jelly (CJ):

  • A gelatinous, cell-free extracellular matrix filling the myoendocardial space of the embryonic heart tube.
  • Function:
    • Acts as a hydraulic skeleton, providing structural support during early heart development. (Option A)
    • Facilitates end-systolic occlusion of the embryonic heart lumen, improving pumping efficiency. (Option B)
    • Stores elastic energy during systole, aiding the refilling phase of the heart. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following is the CO2 absorption capacity of soda lime?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 23L CO2 per 100 gram

 

Explanation:

Soda lime absorbs up to 23 L of CO₂ per 100 g of absorbent

 

Soda lime:

Function
  • Removes carbon dioxide through an exothermic reaction in a closed breathing circuit

Composition
  • Sodium hydroxide
  • Calcium hydroxide
  • Potassium hydroxide
  • Water

Granule size
  • 4 to 8 mesh size

Absorption capacity

  • Soda lime absorbs up to 23 L of CO₂ per 100 g of absorbent.

Chemical Process
  • Sodium and potassium hydroxide neutralize and trap carbon dioxide.
  • Gaseous carbon dioxide is converted into solid calcium carbonate (chalk).

By-products
  • Heat and water are produced during the reaction.
  • Helps maintain the temperature and humidity of the anesthesia circuit.

Indicator
  • A dye (e.g., ethyl violet) changes color from white to purple with increasing hydrogen ion concentration and absorbent exhaustion.

Reaction with anesthetics
  • Dry soda lime can degrade volatile anesthetics (e.g., desflurane, sevoflurane) and produce carbon monoxide.
  • Carbon monoxide formation is greatest with desflurane.

questions.text:
Match the following herpes virus with its corresponding microscopic findings.

 


	
		
			
			1. Herpes Simplex Virus
			
			
			A. 

			
			
		
		
			
			2. Epstein Barr Virus
			
			
			B.

			
			
		
		
			
			3. Cytomegalovirus
			
			
			C.

			
			
		
		
			
			4. Human herpes virus type 8
			
			
			D.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

Explanation:

 

Microscopic features of the herpes virus:

Herpes simplex virus

  • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground-glass' chromatin (Tzanck cells).
  • Formation of Lipschutz bodies (Cowdry type A).

EBV (Epstein Barr virus)

  • Downey cells: Atypical lymphocytes (large, vacuolated) are observed.
  • Ballerina skirt appearance.

CMV (Cytomegalovirus)

  • The presence of inclusion bodies gives the characteristic “Owl-eye appearance”.

HHV 8 (human herpes virus type 8)

  • Castleman disease: Onion skinning of lymphocytes and blood vessels, giving the appearance of “Lollipop follicles”.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled to undergo a Whipple procedure for the treatment of pancreatic cancer. The surgeon needs to perform anastomosis to reconstruct the digestive tract after removing the affected tissues. In which sequence are the anastomoses typically performed during a Whipple procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pancreaticojejunostomy → Hepaticojejunostomy → Gastrojejunostomy

 

Explanation:

The typical sequence for performing anastomosis in a Whipple procedure is to start with the pancreaticojejunostomy, followed by the hepaticojejunostomy, and finally the gastrojejunostomy. This order allows for proper reconstruction of the digestive system following the removal of the affected tissues.

Whipple’s procedure  (Pancreaticoduodenectomy)

Structures removed: Head of the pancreas, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder, and a portion of the bile duct.

Types:

  • Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure (Preferred)
  • Non–Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure

Indications
  • Pancreatic Cancer: Commonly treated with Whipple if cancer is localized to the head of the pancreas.
  • Chronic Pancreatitis: when uncontrolled by medical management.
  • Tumors in Pancreas/Surrounding Areas: Includes duodenum, distal bile duct, and ampulla of Vater.

Procedure Steps
  • Tumor Assessment: Explore abdomen to assess tumor size, location, and spread.
  • Resection: Remove head of pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and part of bile duct; this may include partial stomach resection.
  • Lymph Node Dissection: Remove and examine nearby lymph nodes.

Reconstruction
  • Pancreaticojejunostomy: Connect remaining pancreas to jejunum.
  • Hepaticojejunostomy: Connect common bile duct to jejunum.
  • Gastrojejunostomy: Connect stomach to jejunum.

Anastomosis Principles
  • Tension-Free Connection: Achieve mucosa-to-mucosa connection for healing.
  • Order of Anastomoses: Pancreaticojejunostomy → Hepaticojejunostomy → Gastrojejunostomy
  • Stent Placement: May use internal/external stents for small ducts.

Complications
  • Pancreatic Fistula: Major issue; managed with somatostatin analogues.
  • Delayed Gastric Emptying
  • Bleeding, wound infection
  • Reoperation, increased mortality
  • Dumping/Bile Reflux: Common after non-pylorus-preserving Whipple; pylorus-preserving method has uncertain benefits.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer. Despite taking her prescribed antiemetic medication, she experiences significant nausea and vomiting starting 24 hours after her chemotherapy sessions and lasting for several days. Which of the following is the 1st line drug used to relieve this patient’s chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Aprepitant

Explanation: 

This patient is undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer, after 24 hours of therapy she complained of nausea and vomiting for several days. This suggests a delayed phase in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). The DOC for the same is an NK1 receptor antagonist (e.g; Aprepitant)

 


Palonosetron can be used in the delayed phase by combining it with Dexamethasone. 

Fezolinetant is an NK3 receptor antagonist used to treat postmenopausal vasomotor syndrome (Option C).

questions.text:
Near your home, there is an overhead water tank that needs disinfection. The sanitation officer decides to prepare a solution using high-test hypochlorite.

Which of the following is true regarding high-test hypochlorite?

choices.text: A single tablet of 0.5 g is sufficient to disinfect 20 liters of water.
It is available as Nesfield's and Bursoline's tablets.
It is no longer recommended for water disinfection.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It contains 60-70% available chlorine

Explanation:

  • High-Test Hypochlorite(HTH) or Perchloron is a calcium compound that contains 60-70% of available chlorine.
  • It is more stable than bleaching powder and deteriorates much less in storage
  • Solutions prepared from HTH are also used for water disinfection.

A single tablet of 0.5 g is sufficient to disinfect 20 liters of water (Option A): A single Chlorine (not HTH) tablet of 0.5g is sufficient to disinfect 20 liters of water. 

It is available as Nesfield's and Bursoline's tablets (Option C): Nesfield's and Bursoline's tablets are Iodine tablets. Iodine is used for emergency disinfection of water. 2 drops of 2% ethanol solution of iodine will suffice for one liter of clear water, contact time of 20-30 min.

It is no longer recommended for water disinfection (Option D): HTH is still recommended for water disinfection. Rather, Potassium permanganate, a powerful oxidizing agent, once widely used for disinfection, is now no longer recommended.

questions.text:
A 45 y/o male presents with right-sided flank pain and recurrent urinary tract infections. The imaging study is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Retro-caval ureter

 

Explanation:

Imaging shows a medial deviation of the right ureter. A retro-caval ureter is caused by a developmental anomaly in which the ureter is trapped behind the IVC due to improper embryological development of the vena cava. This leads to a characteristic medial deviation of the ureter at the L3-L4 level. Patients with this condition often present with flank pain, recurrent urinary tract infections, and hydronephrosis due to impaired urine flow through the kinked or obstructed ureter. 

 

 

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (Option A): This condition occurs when urine flows backwards from the bladder into the ureters, leading to recurrent urinary infections and kidney damage. While it can result in hydronephrosis and recurrent infections, it is not associated with medial deviation of the ureter.

 

Transitional cell carcinoma (Option B): This type of cancer affects the lining of the urinary tract, most commonly the bladder and ureters. It can cause symptoms like hematuria and flank pain, but it is not associated with the specific imaging feature of medial deviation of the ureter. Instead, transitional cell carcinoma typically presents with filling defects and dilatation of the ureter above the tumour giving a, known as the "goblet sign," and does not lead to the ureter passing behind the IVC. 

 

 

Polycystic kidney disease (Option C): This genetic disorder is characterised by the growth of numerous fluid-filled cysts in the kidneys, leading to enlarged kidneys and impaired function and is not linked to ureter deviation or hydronephrosis.

questions.text: All the factors inhibit gastric emptying except?

choices.text: A large volume of solid meals

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypotonic solution in duodenum

Explanation:

Hypotonic solutions do not inhibit gastric emptying. In fact, they may even promote faster gastric emptying due to their lower osmolarity.

Factors Promoting Gastric Emptying:

Factor

Mechanism

Vagal stimulation

Stimulates antral contraction, promoting gastric emptying

Liquid meal

Faster gastric emptying due to lower viscosity and faster transit through the stomach

Motilin

Stimulates antral contraction and gastric emptying, especially during the interdigestive state

 

Factors Inhibiting Gastric Emptying:

 

Factor

Mechanism

Acid in the duodenum

Releases secretin, inhibiting antral contraction and stimulating pyloric sphincter contraction

Products of fat digestion

Releases CCK and GIP, inhibiting gastric emptying

Hypertonic solutions in the duodenum

Releases hormones inhibiting gastric emptying

Products of protein digestion

Releases gastrin, CCK, and GIP, inhibiting gastric emptying

Large meal volume (solids)

Prolongs gastric emptying time

Stretching of duodenum

Initiates enterogastric reflex, inhibiting gastric emptying

Sympathetic stimulation

Decreased gastric motility (by norepinephrine) and increased pyloric sphincter tone.

Hormones (CCK, GIP, secretin)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents after a road traffic accident. He experienced a brief loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval. On examination, he has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 13 and exhibits signs of a head injury. A CT scan of the head was performed, and the image revealed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
EDH is often caused by trauma, such as in this road traffic accident, leading to disruption of the middle meningeal artery. The classic presentation includes a brief loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval, typical for EDH. Here the CT, shows a biconvex (lentiform) shaped hematoma that does not cross suture lines. A GCS score of 13 indicates mild impairment, consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Feature

Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH)

Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH) (Option A)

Type of Hemorrhage

Arterial Hemorrhage

Venous Hemorrhage
Shape

Biconvex or lentiform

Crescent or sickle-shaped

Location

Limited by sutures; can cross the midline

Follows the brain surface; crosses sutures, does not cross midline

Cause

Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (MMA)

Rupture of cortical bridging veins

Onset of Symptoms

Often presents with a lucid interval

Symptoms may develop gradually, often without a lucid interval

Force Required

Requires more force; associated with adjacent bony rupture

Can occur with trivial trauma

Midline Crossing

Can cross the midline

Does not cross the midline

Lucid Interval

Yes; patient appears normal before deterioration

No; deterioration may be more gradual

Clinical Signs

Symptoms may include headache, loss of consciousness, and focal neurological deficits

Symptoms may include headache, confusion, and potential focal deficits

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) (Option C): SAH presents with bleeding in the subarachnoid space and shows diffuse blood in the sulci and cisterns rather than a localized collection.

 

Cerebral contusion (Option D): Cerebral contusions typically appear as areas of brain parenchymal damage and do not exhibit the characteristic biconvex shape seen in this case.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhoea, abdominal bloating, and unintended weight loss. She reports discomfort after consuming gluten-containing foods. Laboratory tests show elevated tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA) levels, prompting a small intestinal biopsy via upper endoscopy. Which of the following combinations of histopathological features will be seen in this condition?


	Intraepithelial CD8+ T Lymphocytes
	Crypt hyperplasia
	Villous atrophy
	Decreased mitotic activity
	Inflammatory cell infiltration in lamina propria
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 3, 5

Explanation:

The clinical scenario is classic for Celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten ingestion, confirmed by:

  • Positive anti-tTG and anti-EMA antibodies

  • Small bowel biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis

Marsh criteria of celiac disease: Because the antibodies are formed due to consumption of gluten, they first attack the villi of intestine (Villous atrophy)

Histopathological features in Celiac disease:

Feature Seen in Celiac? Explanation
1. Intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes Yes Early and sensitive marker of immune response
2. Crypt hyperplasia Yes Compensatory response due to villous damage
3. Villous atrophy Yes Hallmark feature; leads to malabsorption
4. Decreased mitotic activity No Mitotic activity is increased because of increased inflammation and proliferation, not decreased
5. Inflammatory cell infiltration in LP Yes Mainly lymphocytes and plasma cells in lamina propria

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant presents with recurrent ear infections, eczema, and petechiae. He has a history of prolonged bleeding from the umbilical stump. His complete blood count reveals thrombocytopenia with small platelets. Immunoglobulin levels show low IgM and elevated IgA and IgE. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome

Definition
  • Rare X-linked recessive disorder affecting males; characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immunodeficiency.

Genetic Basis
  • Caused by mutations in the WASP gene, affecting actin cytoskeleton in blood cells.

Clinical Features
  • Eczema: Develops within the first year; ranges from mild to severe.
  • Thrombocytopenia: Present at birth; leads to prolonged bleeding from the umbilical stump, easy bruising, petechiae, and purpura.
  • Immunodeficiency: Susceptible to infections (bacterial, viral, opportunistic); increased risk of autoimmune disorders and malignancies (lymphomas, leukemia).

Diagnosis
  • Clinical Triad: Eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immunodeficiency.
  • Lab Tests: CBC (small, abnormally shaped platelets), immunoglobulin levels (low IgM, high IgA and IgE), lymphocyte subset analysis (low T cells), genetic testing (WASP mutations).
  • Mnemonic: WATER-WASP gene mutation, Thrombocytopenia, Eczema, Recurrent infections

Treatment
  • Supportive Care: Preventative antibiotics, immunoglobulin replacement, eczema management, use of killed vaccines.
  • Curative Treatment: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)

Prognosis
  • Without HSCT: Often fatal in childhood due to infections, bleeding, or malignancies.
  • With HSCT: Can significantly improve life expectancy; risks include graft-versus-host disease (GvHD).

 

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) (Option A) presents with severe immunodeficiency but typically lacks thrombocytopenia or small platelets.

 

Henoch-Schonlein purpura (Option B) is characterised by palpable purpura, joint Involvement, abdominal pain, and renal involvement, but does not usually present with eczema or thrombocytopenia.

 

Ataxia-Telangiectasia (Option D) involves cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasia and immunodeficiency but does not present with thrombocytopenia or eczema.

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of labour in the correct sequence.

 


	Descent
	Flexion
	Engagement
	Internal rotation
	Delivery of posterior shoulder
	Extension
	External rotation
	Delivery of anterior shoulder
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

 

Explanation:

 

Normal labour:

 

Series of events that take place in the genital organs in an effort to expel the viable products of conception (fetus, placenta and the membranes) out of the womb through the vagina. The steps in normal labour include:

 

Engagement (widest part of the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet).

↓

Descent (fetal head moves downward into the pelvis).

↓

Flexion (fetal head bends forward so the smallest diameter enters the pelvis).

↓

Internal rotation (fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis).

↓

Extension (fetal head extends as it passes under the pubic symphysis).

↓

Restitution (passive head movement due to neck untwisting during internal rotation).

↓

External rotation (fetal head rotates externally to align with the shoulders).

↓

Delivery of the anterior shoulder followed by the posterior shoulder of the fetus.

↓

questions.text: A 5-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in coordinating movements, slurred speech, and frequent infections. Physical examination reveals the findings shown in the image below and dysarthria. Laboratory investigations show decreased levels of serum IgA, IgG, and IgE. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ataxia Telangiectasia

Explanation:

The clinical scenario (dysarthria, slurred speech, recurrent infections, telangiectasia shown in the image above, decreased serum IgA, IgG, and IgE) suggests ataxia telangiectasia.

  • Ataxia Telangiectasia (AT) is an autosomal-recessive disorder.
  • Key features: abnormal gait (ataxia), vascular malformations (telangiectases), neurological deficits, increased tumors, and immunodeficiency.
  • Immunodeficiency impacts both B and T cells, mainly causing defective production of IgA and IgG2 antibodies.
  • Thymic hypoplasia often results in milder T-cell defects.
  • Patients frequently experience respiratory tract infections, autoimmune issues, and higher cancer risks.
  • Caused by a mutation in the gene on chromosome 11 encoding the ATM protein kinase.
  • ATM activates p53 in response to DNA damage, prompting cell cycle checkpoints and apoptosis. ATM deficiency impairs DNA repair, affecting antigen receptor generation and Ig isotype switching.
  • Significantly increased risk of lymphoma in AT patients.

Hereditary spastic paraplegia (Option A) presents with spasticity in the lower limbs but does not typically involve cerebellar dysfunction or telangiectasias.

Friedreich ataxia (Option B) is a trinucleotide repeat disorder that presents with progressive gait and limb ataxia but does not typically present with telangiectasias or immunodeficiency.

Spinocerebellar ataxia (Option D) type 1 is characterised by progressive cerebellar ataxia but does not typically present with telangiectasias or immunodeficiency.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was found dead after a suspected shooting incident involving a shotgun. During the investigation, experts examined the shotgun's characteristics to determine factors affecting its range. Which of the following does not enhance the range of shotguns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Elongated and pointed bullet

 

Explanation:

An elongated and pointed bullet does not enhance the effective range of shotguns.

 

Factors Enhancing the Range of Firearms

  1. Shotgun

Paradox gun: A mixed gun incorporating characteristics of both a rifle and a shotgun, featuring a shotgun design with a rifled section in the barrel towards the muzzle end.

  • Choking: Constriction at the muzzle end of a shotgun in order to:
    • Reduce the dispersion of lead shot
    • Enhance the velocity of the pellets

 

  • Types of choking:

Type

Range

Cylindrical base (unchoked)

25 yards

Improved cylindrical choke

30 yads

Modified cylindrical choke

35 yards

Full choke

40 yards

 

 

 

  1. Rifled Firearm
  • Elongated and pointed bullet (Option A): Aerodynamic shape reduces air resistance, allowing the bullet to maintain velocity and travel farther.
  • Lands and Grooves (Rifling) (Option B): Imparts spin to the bullet, stabilising it in flight and improving accuracy and range.
  • Calibre (Distance between two opposite lands) (Option C): Larger calibers maintain stability and energy over longer distances, contributing to extended range.

 

 

 

  • Barrel length: A longer barrel increases bullet velocity by allowing more time for propellant gases to act, enhancing range.
  • Ammunition Type: High-performance bullets reduce drag, improving aerodynamic efficiency and range.
  • Muzzle Velocity: Higher initial bullet speed reduces the effects of gravity and air resistance, extending range.

questions.text: Which maternal health initiative is not under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pradhan mantri matru vandana yojana


 

Explanation:

Other schemes under MWCD

  • ICDS
  • SABLA
  • PMMVY
  • UJAWALA (to prevent trafficking of women and children)

 

Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (Option A)

 
  • This program is under the Ministry of Women and Child Development.
  • Cash incentive is given only up to 1 birth.
  • Cash incentive of Rs. 6000 given in 2 installments:
    • First Installment: ₹3,000 is given after the beneficiary registers her pregnancy and meets early antenatal care conditions, such as taking iron-folic acid tablets and receiving the first tetanus toxoid injection.
    • Second Installment: ₹3,000 is provided after delivery, following birth registration and initial immunization of the newborn with vaccines such as BCG, OPV, and Hepatitis

Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (Option B)
  • On the 9th of every month, free antenatal services are provided to women, particularly in the 2nd or 3rd trimester, in government and private facilities that are part of the scheme.
  • Aim - To identify high-risk pregnancies on time.
  • This program is under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
  • Red card - Women at high risk.
  • Green card - Women at no risk
  • Blue card - Woman is a case of PIH
  • Yellow card - Women with comorbidities (Diabetes, Thyroid)

Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN) Scheme (Option C)

  • This is also under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
  • Initiative: Zero preventable maternal and newborn deaths.
  • Beneficiaries:
    • Pregnant women during the antenatal period
    • Women during delivery
    • Women up to 6 months post-delivery
    • Sick neonates
  • Total number of services provided- 18

Maa Programme (Mother's Absolute Affection) (Option D)
  • Aim- To promote breastfeeding.
  • Under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
  • Functions:
    • Lactation counselling and breastfeeding initiations.
    • Stimulation and expression support through electric breast pumps
    • Collection, storage, processing and dispensing of donor human milk

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of the triple deformity in tuberculosis of the knee?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lateral displacement of the patella

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral displacement of the patella is not a typical feature of the triple deformity; the primary features involve changes in the tibia and knee flexion rather than patellar positioning.

 

TB knee stages

 

1. Synovitis
  • Boggy swelling

2. Early Arthritis
  • Severe pain and swelling.

3. Late Arthritis/Pathological dislocation
  • Triple deformity (Options A, C, and D)

    • External or lateral rotation of the tibia (due to spasm of the iliotibial band)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male has a history of recurrent wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath. His sputum microscopy, shown in the image below, reveals the following finding. Which best describes this finding?

choices.text: Extrusion of mucus plugs from the subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles.
Ciliated columnar cells sloughed from the bronchial mucosa.
Polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within the bronchioles.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) They are composed of Galectin 10.

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation points towards a diagnosis of bronchial asthma, with sputum culture showing Charcot-Leyden crystals

Charcot-Leyden crystals:

  • They are microscopic, needle-shaped crystals that are often found in the sputum of asthma patients, particularly during exacerbations.
  • They are primarily composed of galectin-10 (derived from the eosinophils) also known as Charcot-Leyden crystal protein (CLC).
  • Strong inducers of inflammation and mucus production.

 

  • Extrusion of mucus plugs from the subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles describes the Curschmann spirals. They are a characteristic finding in asthma. (Option A)

  • Ciliated columnar cells sloughed from the bronchial mucosa describe the Creola bodies seen in bronchial asthma. (Option B)

  • Polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within the bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and alveoli describe Masson bodies, which are seen in cryptogenic organising pneumonia. (Option C)

questions.text: “A factory worker was exposed to asbestos for 20 years starting in the 1980s. 30 years later, he developed mesothelioma.” This scenario is an example of?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A- Temporal association

Explanation:

The given scenario is an example of Temporal association.

Temporal association:

  • The cause must precede the observed effect.
  • In chronic diseases, establishing temporal sequence can be challenging due to insidious onset and ignorance of precise induction periods.
  • Example: Lung cancer occurring in long-term smokers satisfies the temporal requirement.

 

Hill's criteria for causation are a group of 9 principles that can be useful in establishing epidemiologic evidence of a causal relationship between a presumed cause and an observed effect and have been widely used in public health research.

Different principles are as follows:

  • Temporality
  • Strength
  • Specificity
  • Consistency
  • Plausibility
  • Coherence
  • Analogy
  • Gradient
  • Experiment

 

Strength of association (Option B) refers to how strong the link is between exposure and disease (e.g., measured statistically with risk ratios).

Consistency of association(Option C) refers to whether the same association is observed across different studies and populations

Biological plausibility(Option D) refers to whether the association makes sense based on known biological mechanisms (asbestos causing mesothelioma is biologically plausible, but that's not what's being illustrated here).

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with positive ANA > 1:80 report presents with SOB and scanty frothy urine for the past 1 week. Vitals: BP 180/120 mmHg, HR 88/min. Urinalysis reveals 3+ protein, RBC casts, and granular casts. 24-hour urine protein is 2.8 g/day. Serum creatinine is 4.8 mg/dL. The following appearance of hands is noted along with HRCT chest First differential diagnosis is
questions.solution: Hand appearance shows loss of skin creases in IP joints. HRCT chest shows pulmonary fibrosis. Kidney function is deranged with severe hypertension. All of these point to Scleroderma. SLE does not have this hand skin changes and pulmonary fibrosis. Option D has mechanic hands.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of colorectal cancer underwent surgery 3 weeks ago and is now presenting with complaints of left leg swelling and pain for 3 days. His left calf is 4 cm larger than the right. Using Wells' criteria for DVT, what is his pre-test probability score and risk category?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 4 points; High risk

 

Explanation:

The Modified Wells' criteria for Deep Vein Thrombosis is a clinical prediction rule used to estimate the pretest probability for DVT. It helps clinicians determine the need for further diagnostic testing.

The patient scores 4 points (Option C) on the Wells' criteria, placing them in the high-risk category.

  • Malignancy (Including treatment done within past 6 month) (1 point)
  • Recently bedridden for >3 days or major surgery within last 4 weeks (1 point)
  • Calf swelling > 3 cm compared to the other leg (1 point)
  • Entire leg swollen (1 point)

 

This scoring system, when combined with D-dimer testing, helps in the diagnostic algorithm for DVT, potentially reducing unnecessary imaging studies in low-risk patients.

Modified Well’s criteria for detecting DVT:

Variable

Score

Lower limb trauma or surgery or immobilization in a plaster cast

1

Bedridden for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks

1

Tenderness along the line of femoral or popliteal veins

1

Entire limb swollen

1

Calf >3 cm larger circumference than another side 10 cm below the tibial tuberosity

1

Pitting oedema

1

Dilated collateral superficial veins (not varicose veins)

1

Previous DVT

1

Malignancy (including treatment up to 6 months ago)

1

Intravenous drug abuse

3

Alternative diagnosis more likely than DVT

-2
  • Low probability (5%) of DVT: score –2 to 0
  • Moderate probability (17%) of DVT: score 1 or 2
  • High probability (17–53%) of DVT: score >2

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with acute abdominal pain, and bilious vomiting. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen, and he has not had a bowel movement for three days. An abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Start IV fluids (RL)

 

Explanation:

  • The patient’s presentation of acute abdominal pain, distension, and bilious vomiting, along with the abdominal X-ray findings showing dilated bowel loops and valvulae conniventes, confirms the diagnosis of small bowel obstruction (SBO). T
  • he best initial step is to start IV fluids (RL).

 

 

 

Management of Small Bowel Obstruction:

  • Initial Steps:
    • NIL per oral
    • Insert 2 large-bore IV cannulas.
    • Start IV fluids. (Option B)
      • Fluid of choice: Ringer's lactate.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis related to the image:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence

Explanation:

The image shows a typical presentation of Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence, characterized by an acardiac twin, an amorphous mass without a heart, and a normal twin.

  • The acardiac twin receives blood from the normal twin via A-V anastomosis, which can lead to high-output cardiac failure in the normal twin.
  • This deoxygenated blood, which keeps the recipient twin alive, however, goes only to the baby's lower limb, resulting in a mass of flesh with a very small head and properly formed lower limbs.
  • There’s also an impending risk of cardiac failure in the donor baby as it is pumping blood to itself as well as into the recipient baby.
  • Diagnosis is mainly done by USG Doppler or MRI.
  • The main modality of treatment is by ligation of the umbilical cord (laser or RFA) of the acardiac twin under fetoscopic guidance.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male agricultural worker from a rural area presents with an extensive slowly growing, warty, nodular lesion on his lower leg as shown in the image below. The lesion is dark, and rough, and resembles the surface of cauliflower. He recalls injuring his leg on a thorn while working barefoot in the fields several months ago. A KOH mount of the skin specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Chromoblastomycosis

 

Explanation:

Chromoblastomycosis is a fungal infection often seen in individuals from tropical regions who have sustained trauma, such as an injury from a thorn. It commonly presents as slowly growing, warty, nodular lesions resembling cauliflower. The presence of sclerotic bodies (round, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septate) in KOH mounts is characteristic, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Chromoblastomycosis (Also known as verrucous dermatitis)

Epidemiology

It is the most common form of chromomycosis.

Common among barefoot agricultural workers and woodcutters.

Tropical region.

Causative agents

Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, Exophiala dermatitidis, Phialophora, Cladophialophora.

Route of transmission

Infecting fungi enter the skin by traumatic implantation.

Clinical manifestation

Warty, cutaneous nodular lesions (resemble the florets of cauliflower).

Usually confined to subcutaneous tissue of the feet and lower legs

Slow-developing lesions around the site of implantation.

Chromoblastomycosis foot" data-author="" data-hash="10182" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/XDM2CdVMChdG0KscAB1w1744476678.png" />

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy: The lesions show the presence of the fungus as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septate, called sclerotic bodies (other names: muriform bodies, copper pennies, medlar bodies).

Sclerotic cells" data-author="" data-hash="10185" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/vw70kUv1HY15bZZnjgC31744476801.png" />

Demonstration of these sclerotic bodies in KOH mounts or tissue sections, and by culture on Sabouraud agar.

Treatment

Medical: Amphotericin B, thiabendazole, 5-fluorocytosine, itraconazole and (new drug) voriconazole.

Surgical excision.

 

Rhinosporidiosis (Option A): It is a chronic infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It typically presents as polypoid masses in the nasal cavity, conjunctiva, or other mucosal surfaces, not as warty, nodular skin lesions. KOH mounts do not show sclerotic bodies. This option is incorrect.

Rhinosporidiosis nose and histopath" data-author="" data-hash="10187" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/uqLTrwGoVmKDuHix8pzM1744476900.jpg" />

 

Mycotic Mycetoma (Option C): It is caused by the fungi Madurella mycetomatis. It presents as a chronic infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and sometimes bone, usually in the feet. It manifests as nodules that can develop into draining sinuses and does not typically form warty lesions or display sclerotic bodies in microscopy. This option is incorrect.

KOH mount of M. mycetoma

 

Sporotrichosis (Option D): It is caused by Sporothrix schenckii, often occurs after a traumatic implantation and typically presents with nodular lesions that can ulcerate, forming a lymphatic spread pattern. Microscopy of sporotrichosis shows cigar-shaped yeast cells instead. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Calculate Renal Plasma Flow (RPF) if the GFR is 125 ml/min and the Filtration Fraction (FF) is 0.2.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 625

 

Explanation:

 

Filtration fraction is the fraction of renal plasma flow that is filtered.

 

Filtration fraction = GFR/Renal Plasma Flow

 

0.2 = 125/Renal Plasma Flow

 

Renal Plasma Flow = 125/0.2=625

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of breast cancer presents to the emergency department with progressive confusion, nausea, severe constipation, and weakness for the past 2 days. Vitals: BP 90/60 mmHg, HR 112/min, RR 22/min, Temp 37.1°C. ECG shows shortened QT interval. Labs reveal: Na⁺ 132 mEq/L, K⁺ 3.2 mEq/L, Ca²⁺ (total) 13.5 mg/dL, creatinine 2.1 mg/dL, and BUN 48 mg/dL. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Start IV furosemide and restrict fluids
Begin IV normal saline infusion and monitor urine output

questions.solution: Patient of breast cancer is having hypercalcemic crisis. Start fluids first to lower risk of cardiac arrest. Saline hydration restores renal perfusion and allows excretion of calcium.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive hearing loss in his left ear over the past few years. Audiometry shows hearing loss predominantly in lower frequencies, and otoscopic examination reveals a normal tympanic membrane. The patient denies experiencing tinnitus or vertigo. The patient’s hearing loss is mild and not significantly affecting his daily life. What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Observation and monitoring

 

Explanation:

This presentation is consistent with Stapedial otosclerosis.

In mild cases of stapedial otosclerosis where hearing loss is not significantly impacting daily life, observation with regular hearing tests is the preferred initial approach.

 

Medical Management of Otosclerosis

Management is individualized based on whether the otosclerosis is stapedial (middle ear) or cochlear (inner ear), focusing on hearing loss and quality of life.

 

For Stapedial Otosclerosis

  • Observation & Monitoring: (Option C)
    • Recommended for mild cases or when hearing loss is not severe.
    • Regular audiograms track hearing loss progression.
  • Hearing Aids:
    • Effective for conductive hearing loss due to the fixed stapes.
    • Non-invasive option to improve sound transmission.

 

For Cochlear Otosclerosis

  • Hearing Aids:
    • May help but are less effective for severe sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Symptom Management:
    • Tinnitus: Managed with sound or tinnitus retraining therapy.
    • Vertigo: May improve with hearing treatment; other therapies could be needed.

 

Medications for otosclerosis:

Treatment

Mechanism

Duration

Benefits

Sodium Fluoride (NaF) (Option D)

Stabilizes hearing thresholds and vestibular symptoms. Combined with calcium carbonate and vitamin D for enhanced effect.

At least 6 months

Delays worsening tinnitus

Reduces conductive and sensorineural hearing loss

Bisphosphonates (Option B)

Stabilizes hearing loss, reduces dizziness and tinnitus.

At least 6 months

Stabilizes hearing loss

Relieves vestibular symptoms

 

Immediate stapedectomy surgery (Option A): Surgery is considered in more advanced or symptomatic cases. In case of bilateral otosclerosis the worse ear is operated first and a wait time of 6 months is warranted before next surgery. C/I: Positive Schwartz sign, Pregnancy, active infection, only hearing ear, flying, diving and working at height.
