questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease and started on drugs for the same 6 months ago. She now presents for a review with complaints of skin discolouration, as shown in the image below. Which of the following antiparkinson agents would have caused this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amantadine

Explanation:

  • The skin discolouration given above, with a history of treatment for Parkinsonism, is suggestive of livedo reticularis, which can occur as a side effect of using amantadine.
  • Livedo reticularis occurs due to the release of catecholamines, which result in peripheral vasoconstriction.

Other side effects of Amantadine:

  • Insomnia.
  • Restlessness.
  • Confusion.
  • Nightmares.
  • Anticholinergic effects.
  • Hallucinations (rare).
  • Ankle oedema.

questions.text: A 25 y/o woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain, an enlarged uterus, and elevated beta-hCG levels, suggesting molar pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. An Ultrasound finding of the ovaries is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Theca lutein cysts

 

Explanation:

In Molar pregnancy, ovaries may appear fuller and cystic on ultrasound due to multiple theca-lutein cysts, which are more common with complete moles.

 

Theca Lutein Cysts:

  • These cysts are commonly associated with molar pregnancy due to high beta-hCG levels overstimulating the ovaries.
  • hCG and Luteinising hormone share the same receptor, stimulating the theca layer around follicles.
  • Management: Theca-lutein cysts typically regress after pregnancy evacuation and hCG level decline, favoring expectant management.
  • Complications: Larger cysts may occasionally undergo torsion, infarction, and hemorrhage.
  • Theca lutein cysts larger than 6cm in diameter are a potential risk factor for a malignant change in molar pregnancy, leading to choriocarcinoma.


 

Functional ovarian cysts (Option A) are common and usually associated with the menstrual cycle. They do not typically present with such markedly elevated beta-hCG levels or in the context of a molar pregnancy.

 

Endometriomas (Option B) are related to endometriosis and would not be associated with molar pregnancy.

 

Dermoid cysts (Option C) (mature cystic teratomas) are unrelated to pregnancy and would not explain the elevated beta-hCG levels.

questions.text: A 40 year old female presents with AUB associated with chronic pelvic pain for the past two years. TVS shows anteroposterior asymmetry of the uterus and heterogeneous myometrial texture. What will you most likely see on HPE if this patient is diagnosed with adenomyosis?

choices.text: Glandular endometrial tissue surrounded by stromal cells in myometrium
Hyperplastic endometrial glands with mitotic bodies
Whorled pattern of well-differentiated smooth muscle fibres
Necrotic endometrial tissue with chronic inflammation and lymphocytic infiltrate

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glandular endometrial tissue surrounded by stromal cells in myometrium

 

Explanation:

Histopathological examination of adenomyosis shows infiltration of the myometrium by the endometrial tissue; thus, we can observe glandular endometrial tissue surrounded by stromal cells in the myometrium.


 

Hyperplastic endometrial glands with mitotic bodies (Option B): Hyperplastic endometrial glands with mitotic bodies are a characteristic finding of endometrial hyperplasia.

 

A whorled pattern of well-differentiated smooth muscle fibers (Option C): Histopathology of Leiomyoma/fibroids shows a well-defined whorled pattern of well-differentiated smooth muscle fibers.

 

Necrotic endometrial tissue with lymphocytic infiltrate (Option D): Necrotic endometrial tissue with lymphocytic infiltration suggests chronic inflammation, which can be seen in endometritis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to ER for acute onset confusion, seizures, and behavioral changes for the past 2 days. She has a past history of hypothyroidism for which she is on levothyroxine. On exam: BP 130/80 mmHg, HR 84/min, Temp 37.1°C. Neurological exam reveals altered sensorium and generalized hyperreflexia. TSH is mildly elevated, T4 is low and T3 is low. CSF shows elevated protein with normal cell count. MRI brain is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Myxedema coma presents with bradycardia, hypothermia and coma and not seizures. Thyroid storm presents with hyperthermia, tachycardia, delirium and high T4 and T3. Sick euthyroid syndrome presents with critical illness like sepsis with normal T4 and low T3. It does not have neuro features. The question can be solved by exclusion.

questions.text:
A stillborn baby was noted to have the following findings.



The above pathology is derived from which among the following structure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2

 

Explanation:

The pathology shown is Oropharyngeal teratoma, arises from Primordial germ cells that fail to migrate to the gonadal ridge and Primordial germ cells (PGC) in the image corresponds to “2”.

Markings in the image are:

1 - Allantois

2 - Primordial Germ cells (Option B)

3 - Yolk sac

4 - Heart

Primordial Germ Cells (PGC):

Origin and Migration of Primordial Germ Cells (PGC)

2nd week:

  • PGC originate in the epiblast and migrate through the primitive streak.

3rd week:
  • They are located among endoderm cells in the wall of the yolk sac, close to the allantois.

4th week:
  • The PGC migrate by ameboid movement along the dorsal mesentery of the hindgut.

5th week:
  • They arrive at the primitive gonads.

6th week:
  • Invade the genital ridges.

Gonads
  • Shortly before and during the arrival of primordial germ cells, the epithelium of the genital ridge starts to proliferate.
  • Epithelial cells penetrate the underlying mesenchyme, forming primitive sex cords, which are irregularly shaped.
  • In both male and female embryos, the primitive sex cords are connected to the surface epithelium.
  • At this stage, the gonad is called the indifferent gonad, as there is no distinction between male and female gonads yet.

Pathologies associated: due to failure of migration of PGC
  • Teratoma (oropharyngeal/sacrococcygeal)
  • Non development of gonads

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with complaints of infertility and chronic lower abdominal pain for the past year. She mentions recent unintentional weight loss and occasional night sweats. Her menstrual cycles have been regular, but she has experienced heavier-than-usual periods over the past six months. Considering her symptoms and clinical history, the clinician suspects endometrial tuberculosis and decides to perform an endometrial biopsy for diagnosis.

Which is the best time to perform an endometrial biopsy to diagnose endometrial tuberculosis?

choices.text: Any time during the menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) During the late premenstrual phase

Explanation:

The optimal time to perform an endometrial biopsy for diagnosing endometrial tuberculosis is during the late premenstrual phase of the menstrual cycle.

  • The tubercle is found in the basal layer of the endometrium and moves to the surface before menstruation. Following the shedding of the endometrium during menstruation, reinfection arises from the basal layer lesions or the fallopian tubes.

Layers affected: Endometrial tuberculosis typically affects the endometrial layer (60%) while sparing the myometrium.

Endometrial biopsy is done during the premenstrual period by D&C or hysteroscopy directed biopsy. Menstrual blood collected on the first day of menstruation (superficial layer is shed off) can also be used as a diagnostic sample because it may contain the bacilli responsible for the infection.

questions.text: A term newborn, delivered via LSCS to a 30-year-old G2P1 woman with O-negative blood type and inadequate prenatal care, presents with generalized edema, ascites, pallor, severe respiratory distress, and hepatosplenomegaly. The infant is critically ill and admitted to the NICU. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hydrops Fetalis

 

Explanation:

The baby looks pale and edematous with an enlarged abdomen due to ascites, this is characteristic of Hydrops fetalis, a form of hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN). 

  • Hydrops is diagnosed by identifying two or more fetal effusions – pleural, pericardial, or ascites – or one effusion plus anasarca. 
  • Pathophysiology of hydrops fetalis:

Congenital Anemia of the Newborn (Option A) is the mildest form of HDFN, characterized by slow destruction of RBCs in the first few weeks of life, leading to anemia, enlarged liver, and spleen, but typically without noticeable jaundice. Unlike Hydrops fetalis, it does not present with edema and ascites in the baby.

 

Icterus Gravis Neonatorum (Option B) is the moderate form of HDFN presents as jaundice, developing within 24 hours of birth due to a build-up of unconjugated bilirubin, a by-product of RBC breakdown. The infant's liver can't process the excess bilirubin, which can reach toxic levels and potentially lead to kernicterus, a type of brain damage. The baby in this scenario has anasarca, indicating Hydrops fetalis.

 

Prematurity (Option C): The given condition does not indicate prematurity.

questions.text:
Match each type of thyroid tumour with its most commonly associated risk factor:

 


	
		
			
			Thyroid Carcinoma
			
			
			Risk Factors:
			
		
		
			
			1. Papillary thyroid carcinoma
			
			
			A. Iodine deficiency
			
		
		
			
			2. Follicular thyroid carcinoma
			
			
			B. RET proto-oncogene mutations
			
		
		
			
			3. Medullary thyroid carcinoma
			
			
			C. Radiation exposure
			
		
		
			
			4. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma
			
			
			D. History of a well-differentiated

			follicular neoplasm
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A)1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

Explanation:

 

Thyroid Cancer Type

Risk Factors

 Features

Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma
  • Radiation exposure (especially in childhood)
  • Family history of thyroid cancer
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Thyroglossal cyst
  • Most common mutation: BRAFV600E
  • Gene fusion: RET/PTC gene fusion

Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Long-standing Goiter.
 Most common genetic alteration: RAS gene mutation

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma
  • RET proto-oncogene mutations.
  • Family history (e.g., MEN2 syndrome)
  

Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma
  • Older age
  • ¼ th of patients have a past history of a well-differentiated follicular neoplasm
  • Previous radiation exposure
 Worst prognosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive bilateral vision loss over the past few months. He reports a history of heavy smoking and alcohol consumption. Examination reveals a centrocecal scotoma in both eyes, and fundoscopy shows mild temporal pallor of the optic discs, as shown in the image. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cyanide

Explanation:

  • Cyanide is a well-established cause of toxic amblyopia, also known as tobacco-alcohol amblyopia.
  • Cyanide, specifically from tobacco smoke, inhibits mitochondrial enzymes, particularly the cytochrome c oxidase in the electron transport chain, leading to a lack of ATP and optic nerve dysfunction.
  • Retinal ganglion cells, being energy-dependent, are especially vulnerable to cyanide’s toxic effects, causing progressive vision loss.
  • The patient's history of heavy smoking and alcohol consumption increases the likelihood of cyanide exposure.
  • The characteristic bilateral vision loss and centrocecal scotoma on fundoscopy are consistent with cyanide toxicity.
     

 

Agents Causing Toxic Amblyopia:

  • Toxic amblyopia results from damage to the optic nerve or retinal ganglion cells due to various exogenous, endogenous, or drug-related causes.
     
  • The following agents are known to cause toxic amblyopia:

Category

Agents

Mechanism of Action

Exogenous Poisons

Tobacco (Cyanide), Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol), Methyl Alcohol (Methanol), Ethylene Glycol (Antifreeze), Lead, Arsenic, Cannabis indica (Tetrahydrocannabinol), Carbon Disulfide (Industrial Solvent)

These toxins directly affect optic nerve function through mitochondrial dysfunction or systemic toxicity.

Medications

Digoxin, Disulfiram, Isoniazid, Chloroquine, Cyanide, Ethambutol, Quinine, Streptomycin, Amiodarone, Sulfasalazine, Vigabatrin

These drugs interfere with cellular metabolism or have neurotoxic effects on the optic nerve, leading to vision loss.

Nutritional Deficiency

B Vitamins (especially B12, Thiamine, Folate)

Deficiencies in these vitamins lead to nerve damage, including the optic nerve.

Metabolic Disorders

Diabetic ketoacidosis, Uremia

These conditions cause metabolic disturbances that can damage the optic nerve.

Methanol (Option A) causes acute vision loss with systemic symptoms such as metabolic acidosis, which is absent in this patient’s presentation.
 

Arsenic (Option C): Chronic arsenic exposure can lead to optic nerve damage, but it is typically associated with other systemic symptoms like skin changes or gastrointestinal issues, which this patient does not exhibit.
 

Ethambutol (Option D) is known to cause optic neuropathy, but it is usually seen in patients on tuberculosis treatment. This patient's lack of tuberculosis treatment history and the centrocecal scotoma seen in fundoscopy suggest a different cause, making ethambutol less likely.

questions.text: Which oral anticoagulant is known for inhibiting activated Factor Xa and is used for prophylaxis and treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Apixaban

Explanation:

Apixaban, an oral anticoagulant, directly inhibits activated Factor Xa, thereby reducing clot formation by preventing the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.

 

NOVEL ORAL ANTICOAGULANTS:

Category

Direct Factor Xa Inhibitors

Direct Thrombin Inhibitors

Mechanism of action

Inhibit Factor Xa directly

Inhibit thrombin (Factor IIa) directly

Drugs

Apixaban, Rivaroxaban, Edoxaban, Betrixaban

Dabigatran, Ximelagatran

Uses

  • Prophylaxis of venous thromboembolism following knee or hip replacement surgery.
  • Prophylaxis of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation.
  • Treatment of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

Advantages of novel anticoagulants over warfarin
  • Rapid onset and offset of action.
  • No need for routine laboratory monitoring.
  • Lower risk of bleeding.
  • Fewer drug interactions.

questions.text: In the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, which of the following statements accurately describes the "c wave"?

choices.text: The "c wave" is caused by atrial systole
The "c wave" arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
The "c wave" corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria
The "c wave" is influenced by the fluctuations in venous pressure caused by respiration

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The "c wave" arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction, transmitted through the closed tricuspid valve.


 

Explanation:

The "c wave" arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction, which is transmitted through the closed tricuspid valve.

 

Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) Waveform

 

a wave
  • Caused by atrial systole. (Option A ruled out)
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction. (Option B)
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

x descent
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

v wave
  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria. (Option C ruled out)
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

y descent
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

 

Respiration Influence:

  • Venous pressure decreases during inspiration due to negative intrathoracic pressure. (Option D ruled pout)
  • Venous pressure rises during expiration.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who had been incarcerated for political dissent is reported to have died under suspicious circumstances. The autopsy reveals multiple injuries consistent with physical torture. In considering international guidelines for the medical investigation of such cases, which key document outlines principles and standards for identifying and investigating torture for a Police Surgeon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Istanbul Protocol

Explanation:

Declaration / Document

Focus / Purpose

Istanbul Protocol

Documentation and investigation of torture and ill-treatment

Declaration of Tokyo

Guidelines for doctors on torture related to detention and imprisonment (Option A ruled out)

Declaration of Helsinki

Ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects (Option C ruled out)

Nuremberg Code

Ethics in human experimentation post-WWII (Option D ruled out)

Geneva Conventions

Treatment of combatants and civilians during armed conflict

Declaration of Malta

Guidelines on physicians’ roles during hunger strikes, especially in custodial settings

questions.text: A 45-year-old male tourist from rural Egypt presents with recurrent hematuria and lower abdominal pain. A pelvic radiograph shows a circular calcification resembling a fetal head in the pelvis with associated faint calcification of the distal right ureter. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate next step?

choices.text: Chronic schistosomiasis; obtain urine microscopy for ova
Pelvic tuberculosis; order interferon-gamma release assay
Calcified bladder tumor; schedule CT urography

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chronic schistosomiasis; obtain urine microscopy for ova

 

Explanation:

  • The "fetal head in pelvis" appearance on the pelvic radiograph is pathognomonic for chronic urinary schistosomiasis.
  • Pelvic radiograph shows the classic appearance of the calcified bladder, which resembles a fetal head in the pelvis, with associated faint calcification of the distal right ureter.
  • The patient's origin from rural Egypt, an endemic area for Schistosoma haematobium, further supports this diagnosis.
  • Urine microscopy for ova remains the definitive diagnostic test for schistosomiasis.

questions.text: What is the role of Rogi Kalyan Samiti?

choices.text: Support the functioning of health facilities

Correct answer: D) Support the functioning of health facilities

Explanation:

Aspect

Details

  • Hospital Management Society

Manage hospital affairs, ensure patient welfare, and improve facilities in hospitals.

Structure

Registered society with community members as trustees.

Provided through untied funds for activities related to patient welfare.

Location

It is found in almost all DHs, SDHs, CHCs, and PHCs across India.

questions.text: 18-year-old girl collapses during school assembly. Her ECG shows prolonged PR interval, occasional broad QRS complexes and QT interval 500 msec. What is the most likely underlying cause?

choices.text: Wolf Parkinson white syndrome type A
Wolf Parkinson white syndrome type B

questions.solution: Option A, B and D are pre-excitation syndrome and will have short PR interval. The case has prolonged PR and QT is prolonged. Normal QT is 360 to 440 msec. So the answer is Long QT syndrome and common form of it is called Romano ward. Question is based on your exclusion skills.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is seen in Arteriovenous fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Nicoladoni’s sign

 

Explanation:

  • Nicoladoni’s / Branham’s sign is observed in AVF: \
    • On pressing the artery proximal to the fistula, there is a decrease in the size of the pulsatile mass, disappearance of palpable thrill and decrease in heart rate.

 

Arteriovenous Fistula (AVF)

  • AVF is a communication between an artery and a vein that may be either congenital or acquired (trauma or surgical).
  • Structurally, they are arterialised (become dilated, tortuous and thick-walled).
  • Physiologically, there is an increase in venous return (as blood starts flowing from arteries to veins, which causes an increase in cardiac output, which in turn results in an increase in systolic BP, leading to cardiac failure.
  • On examination, there is a presence of pulsatile swelling, a thrill and auscultation reveals machinery murmur (buzzing continuous murmur)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the rate-limiting step of the urea cycle?

choices.text: It involves the formation of citrulline from ornithine.
It is catalysed by carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I).
It is regulated by argininosuccinate synthetase.
It is controlled by the enzyme argininosuccinate lyase.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is catalysed by carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I).

 

Explanation:

  • The carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I) reaction is the rate-limiting step in the urea cycle.
  • The urea cycle is a cycle of biochemical reactions that produce urea from ammonia.
  • It is also known as the Krebs-Henseleit urea cycle or the Ornithine cycle.
  • It starts in the mitochondria of hepatocytes and ends in the cytoplasm.

 

                     

 

Reactions in the Urea Cycle

Step

Reaction Details

Enzyme Involved and Location

Key Points

Carbamoyl Phosphate Formation
  • Formation of carbamoyl phosphate from ammonia and CO₂ using ATP.
  • Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I (CPS I)
 
  • Mitochondria
  • The rate-limiting step of the urea cycle.
  • Irreversible and allosterically regulated by N-acetyl glutamate (NAG).

Citrulline Formation (Option A)
  • Transfer of carbamoyl phosphate to ornithine to form citrulline.
  • Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)
     
  • Mitochondria
  • Citrulline moves from mitochondria to cytosol for further processing in the urea cycle.

Argininosuccinate Formation (Option C)
  • Citrulline combines with aspartate to form argininosuccinate.
  • Argininosuccinate Synthetase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Requires ATP.
  • Links the urea cycle with the TCA cycle via aspartate.

Argininosuccinate Cleavage (Option D)
  • Cleavage of argininosuccinate into arginine and fumarate.
  • Argininosuccinate Lyase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Fumarate enters the TCA cycle, providing a connection between the urea cycle and other metabolic pathways.

Arginine Cleavage to Ornithine and Urea
  • Hydrolysis of arginine to produce ornithine and urea.
  • Arginase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Ornithine is recycled back into the urea cycle.
  • Urea is excreted by the kidneys, with some urea also entering the intestine.

Fate of Urea
  • Urea is transported to the kidneys, filtered, and excreted in urine.
  • Kidneys/ Intestine
  • Urea excretion is the final step, removing excess nitrogen from the body.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old schoolboy was playing on the monkey bars during recess when he suddenly slipped and fell onto his outstretched hand. He immediately felt intense pain in his wrist. On examination, there is significant swelling and tenderness over the wrist. An X-ray of the wrist reveals specific findings indicative of a fracture. Based on the history, clinical features, and X-ray findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Torus fracture

 

Explanation:

 

  • 10-year-old boy who fell onto an outstretched hand, a common mechanism for wrist injuries in children.
  • The intense pain he experienced immediately after the fall aligns with this type of injury.
  • The X-ray findings show a subtle bulging of the cortex in the distal radius without a visible fracture line, which is characteristic of a torus fracture.
  • This injury occurs due to the flexibility of pediatric bones, resulting in compression rather than a complete break.

 

Torus (buckle) fractures

 

Definition

Torus fractures, also known as buckle fractures, occur when the periosteum (the outer layer of the bone) buckles or compresses, typically due to axial loading forces. This type of fracture is incomplete.


 

Common Sites
  • Most frequently affects long bones, especially the tibia (particularly the lower end near the metaphysis, where bones are more spongy and susceptible to compression).
  • The radius is another common site, particularly in falls involving outstretched hands (FOOSH injuries).

Clinical Features
  • There is minimal swelling and pain over the affected site.
  • Unlike complete fractures, there is no visible bone displacement.

Diagnosis

Radiographs show a subtle buckling of the cortex, but there is no break in bone continuity. The imaging may require careful interpretation to differentiate from complete fractures.

Treatment
  • Immobilization with a plaster of Paris (POP) slab for 4–5 weeks is usually sufficient.
  • Surgery is not needed, as these fractures typically heal well with conservative treatment. Follow-up may include monitoring for any signs of healing or complications.

 

Avulsion Fracture

 

Definition

An avulsion fracture occurs when a tendon or ligament pulls off a piece of bone from its insertion site due to sudden, forceful traction or contraction of the attached muscle.

Avulsion fracture of ACL

Common Sites
  • Tibial Tuberosity: The most common site, often associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease or sports-related injuries.
  • Tendo Achilles (Achilles tendon): Avulsion can occur due to excessive tension or a sudden contraction, especially during sports like running or jumping.

Clinical Features
  • Sudden onset of pain at the site of tendon insertion.
  • Swelling and limited movement are often observed.
  • The patellar tendon is frequently involved, and the small bone fragment pulled by the tendon may fail to reunite properly, leading to non-union.

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is often made based on clinical evaluation and imaging.
  • X-rays may show a small bony fragment at the site of tendon insertion, confirming the avulsion.

Treatment
  • Small fractures are typically treated with rest and immobilization.
  • Larger fragments or cases with non-union often require surgical fixation using mini-screws, followed by immobilization to allow for healing.

Impacted Fracture

 

Definition

An impacted fracture occurs when the broken ends of the bone are driven into each other, resulting in the telescoping of the fragments. This type of fracture may be difficult to detect on X-ray due to minimal displacement.

Common Sites
  • Neck of the Femur: The most commonly affected site, often seen in older adults following a fall.
  • The proximal fragment (head of the femur) is driven into the distal fragment (neck), creating the characteristic impacted fracture.

Clinical Features
  • Patients often experience pain in the groin or hip area and have difficulty bearing weight.
  • There may be a limited range of motion in the affected joint.

Diagnosis

Due to the telescoping of bone fragments, X-rays may show minimal fracture lines, requiring a careful radiographic assessment to ensure an accurate diagnosis.

Treatment
  • Disimpaction of the fracture is crucial and is typically done through gentle manipulation to separate the fragments.
  • If the blood supply to the femoral head is intact, the fracture can be internally fixed using screws or a plate to stabilise the bone and promote healing.


 

Avulsion fracture (Option A):

  • This occurs when a small piece of bone is pulled off by a ligament or tendon.
  • It is less likely in this scenario, which involves a fall on an outstretched hand and not a joint injury.

Impacted fracture (Option B):

  • This occurs when the broken ends of the bone are driven into each other.
  • It would typically show more bone disruption, which is not seen here.

 

Greenstick fracture (Option D):

  • This fracture is also common in children and involves a partial break of the bone, where one side breaks and the other bends.
  • It typically presents with a more visible fracture line compared to the subtle bulging seen in a torus fracture.

questions.text: According to the system, which has the logo below and under the Central Birth and Death Registration Act, 1969, what is the time limit for registering for birth and death events in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 21 days

Explanation: The logo represents the Civil Registration System (Aka Vital Survey of the country) under the Central Births and Deaths Registration Act of 1969, which came into force on April 1st, 1970. The flame represents birth and the circle represents death.

According to this system:

  • Registration of birth and death is compulsory throughout the nation
  • The public reports events occurring in their household, while heads of institutions, such as nursing homes, hotels, and jails, report events occurring in their institutes.
  • The time limit for registering the event of birth and death in India is 21 days.
  • For NRI, the time limit is 90 days.
  • Default leads to a late fee.
  • Since 2018, an Aadhaar number has been a must for registration for Death.

questions.text:
A female patient came with a history of vesicles and bullae in the flexural parts one week ago. She presented to a dermatology clinic today because the lesion has changed. On examination, the following lesion is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pemphigus vegetans

Explanation:

  • The image shows moist, vegetative, hypertrophic plaques located in a flexural region, which is characteristic of pemphigus vegetans.
     
  • The patient has a history of vesicles and bullae, which later ruptured to form vegetative erosions in intertriginous areas- supporting the diagnosis.
     
  • This is a rare variant of pemphigus vulgaris, often misdiagnosed without considering the specific morphology and location of lesions.
     

Pemphigus Vegetans:

  • A variant of pemphigus vulgaris, characterized by vegetating plaques.
     
  • Flexural involvement is typical- especially in areas like groin, axillae, inframammary region.
     
  • Develops after bullae or pustules rupture, leading to:
     
    • Hypertrophic, granulating, exudative erosions.
       
    • Lesions may become foul-smelling and infected.
       
  • Oral mucosa may be involved:
     
    • Cerebriform tongue (called Premlata sign)

 

 

  • Two subtypes:
     
    • Neumann type – more severe, vesiculobullous onset.
    • Hallopeau type – milder, pustular onset leading to vegetative growth.

Differential Diagnoses:

Diagnosis

Key Features

Pemphigus vegetans (Option D)

Vegetating erosions in flexures; post-vesicular phase; cerebriform tongue (Premlata sign); Neumann/Hallopeau types.

Pemphigus foliaceus (Option A)

Crusted erosions in seborrheic areas (face, chest, scalp); no mucosal involvement; superficial blistering.

Endemic PF (fogo selvagem) (Option B)

Seen in rural Brazil/Colombia; associated with black fly bites (Simulium); affects children/young adults.

Condyloma acuminata (Option C)

HPV-related genital warts; soft, pink, verrucous or filiform lesions; no vesicle-bullae history.

Condyloma lata (secondary syphilis)

Flat, moist, broad-based lesions in groin/perineum; painless; seen in syphilis- not relevant here.

 

Pemphigus foliaceus (Option A):
 

  • Incorrect because it causes crusted erosions in seborrheic areas, not vegetative plaques in flexures.
  • Mucosal involvement is absent.

 

Endemic pemphigus foliaceus (Option B):
 

  • Incorrect as it occurs in endemic regions (e.g., Brazil), often in young populations living near black fly–infested rivers.
  • Not associated with vegetative or hypertrophic lesions.

Condyloma acuminata (Option C):
 

  • Incorrect as these are genital warts caused by HPV.
  • Present as verrucous or filiform growths, not hypertrophic vegetating plaques.
  • Condyloma lata, seen in secondary syphilis, are broad-based, flat, moist lesions that typically occur in the intertriginous areas such as the groin and perianal region.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male with chronic leg swelling presents with difficulty pinching the skin over the dorsum of his foot. What is this sign known as?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stemmer's sign

Explanation:

The sign of inability to pinch a fold of skin at the root of the second toe suggesting lymphedema is known as Stemmer’s sign.

 

Clinical features of Lymphedema:

  • Buffalo hump: Refers to a fat pad that develops on the dorsum of foot, often associated with conditions like Cushing’s syndrome or prolonged use of corticosteroids. It is not related to skin pinching or lymphedema (Option A).
  • Square toes: The toes appear square-shaped due to prolonged confinement in tight footwear (Option B).
  • Stemmer's sign: Skin over the dorsum of the foot cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis (Option C).
